title: The Mind Games We Play
summary: Explore common mental biases that affect our thinking, from confirmation bias to the spotlight effect.
content:
We all play little mind games with ourselves every day. These are the tricks our brain pulls without us even noticing. They shape how we think, react, and even how we feel about certain things. Sometimes, they’re harmless, but other times, they can make us overthink or feel stuck.

1. Confirmation Bias

This happens when we only pay attention to things that support what we already believe, and ignore anything that doesn’t.
Example: If we think we’re bad at something, we’ll remember the times we struggled, but ignore the times we did well. Once we have formed an opinion, it’s hard to see past it.

2. Anchoring Effect

This is when we focus too much on the first piece of information we get.
Example: If we see a jacket for $100 and then find another for $50, we might think the second one is a great deal, even if it’s not. Our brains tend to hold onto that first price and use it as a reference.

3. Sunk Cost Fallacy

This happens when we keep putting time or effort into something just because we’ve already invested in it—even if it’s no longer serving us.
Example: Finishing a book we’re not enjoying, just because we’ve read most of it already. We feel like we can’t stop, even if it’s not worth our time.

4. Halo Effect

We let one positive thing about someone or something cloud our judgment about everything else.
Example: If someone is nice or talented at one thing, we assume they’re great at everything else too—even if that’s not true.

5. Spotlight Effect

We think everyone is noticing every little thing we do, when really, most people aren’t paying as much attention as we think.
This overestimation of how much people are watching and judging can make us feel nervous or self-conscious for no reason.

6. Availability Heuristic

We judge something based on what we’ve recently seen or heard.
Example: If we’ve just heard about a plane crash, we might start thinking flying is riskier—even though statistically, flying is safer than driving.

These mind games shape how we think and act every day. Once we recognize them, we can start to think more clearly and make better decisions.
And the best part is, it doesn’t require us to be experts or to overthink it.
Sometimes, just being aware of these tricks our minds pull can help us make better decisions and think more clearly.

title: Insights from Mindset by Carol Dweck
summary: Thoughts on how shifting from a fixed mindset to a growth mindset can change the way we learn, grow, and succeed.
content:
I recently read Mindset by Carol Dweck, who explains that it is not just our abilities or talent that lead to success, but the effort we make and the journey we take to achieve it. She also says that success comes from working hard and being open to learning and improving along the way.

Dweck talks about two types of mindsets: fixed and growth.
People with a fixed mindset believe that their abilities or talent can’t change—they are just the way they are.
On the other hand, people with a growth mindset believe that with effort and learning, they can improve and develop their skills over time.

The book is full of examples. One that stuck with me was the story of the rabbit and the tortoise. I asked my little sister about it. She said she'd want to be the rabbit. I explained why the tortoise is the real winner. It’s not about speed. It’s about persistence and never giving up.

Dweck also writes about grades and tests. She says one test can't show everything about a person's abilities.
It’s like trying to understand a whole story from just one sentence—when we need to look at the bigger picture.
This made me think of the teacup story: if your cup is already full, you can’t take in anything new. We need to empty our cups sometimes to make room for new ideas and challenges.

As I read, I realised that I had a strong fixed mindset. But I wanted to change. I wanted to develop a growth mindset.

The book gave me tools to work on my mindset. One suggestion was to name your fixed mindset.
I called mine Red. I am taking Red along on my journey, listening to what she says, and then responding,

“I know it’s a bit hard, but we can do this. We don’t have anything to lose.”

Changing your mindset is hard and takes time.
I’m ready to work on it. I’m learning to value the effort and the journey—not just the result.
I’m seeing effort as part of the process, not as a failure.

Dweck says,

“Change can be tough, but I've never heard anyone say it wasn't worth it.”

I’m just beginning my journey and still learning, but I’m excited to see how this new mindset will shape who I become.

In conclusion, the book has provided me with some really useful ideas.
I’m looking forward to using what I’ve learned and applying it to my life to make positive changes.

title: Chess: A Fun and Effective Game
summary: A personal take on the mental and social benefits of playing chess, and why it’s a great game to share with others.
content:
Chess is a fascinating game that I've enjoyed learning about, even though I don't play it regularly.
It has many benefits that make it worth trying out.

For one, chess is excellent for your brain.
It makes you think deeply and plan strategically, which really gives your mind a workout.
You need to think through all your possible moves and predict what your opponent might do.
This kind of mental exercise can help improve problem-solving skills, memory, and concentration.

Chess also brings out a healthy sense of competitiveness.
There's a real thrill in matching wits against another player and trying to outsmart them.
But it's a friendly kind of competition—you’re not trying to defeat your opponent, you’re simply trying your best to win the game through your own skill and wit.
This can be a great learning experience, as you can also pick up tips from your opponents.

It also helps you think more deeply and clearly as it exercises your brain, making it stronger and quicker.
The challenges you face while playing help you improve your ability to think critically and solve problems.
These skills are useful not just in chess, but in many other areas of life as well.

Which is also why I'm really looking forward to playing chess with my little sister.
I will be starting to teach her, and I think she’ll really enjoy the challenge.
It will be a great way for us to spend quality time together.
And I hope—and am sure—that she'll even end up being better than me.
Plus, this will be a great opportunity for me to brush up on my own skills as well.

In the end, chess is more than just a game.
It’s a fun way to challenge your mind and enjoy some friendly competition.
It’s also a perfect chance to bond with others.

title: Start Now, Don't Wait for Perfect
summary: Waiting for the perfect moment often means never starting. Progress begins with action, not perfection.
content:
Many of us wait for the “right moment” to begin something important. We want our script to be flawless before filming, to master coding before building, or to have every color before painting. We think we’ll start when everything is just right.

But the truth is, the perfect time rarely comes. Life is unpredictable, full of distractions and surprises. If we keep waiting, we might never begin.

The best time to start is now. You can fix the script after filming. You can learn more while building your project. You can paint with the colors you have. Taking the first step matters more than waiting for everything to be ready. Progress comes from doing.

Yes, some things require planning. But most of the time, starting with what you have is better than not starting at all.

I’ve learned this the hard way. Growth doesn’t come from waiting—it comes from action. It’s okay to begin small and imperfect. You’ll improve along the way.

If something matters to you, don’t wait for the perfect day. Start today. The perfect time may never come—but now is always a good place to begin.

title: Unexpected Gem: 'Leo', the Movie
summary: A heartwarming animated film that surprised me with its humor, lessons, and emotional depth.
content:
One evening, my uncle played the animated movie Leo for my sister during dinner—a routine we barely noticed at first. But as the story unfolded, something unexpected happened: we couldn’t look away. Dinner ended, dishes were cleared, and yet, we stayed, completely pulled into Leo’s world.

Leo follows a chameleon who believes he’s nearing the end of his life. Wanting one last adventure, he dreams of escaping to the Everglades. But when school kids take him home on weekends, he ends up helping them with their worries instead. Through quiet conversations and heartfelt advice, Leo teaches them to accept themselves and break free from the weight of expectations.

The friendships Leo forms are what truly stayed with me. He becomes a safe space for the kids, someone who listens and understands. It’s a beautiful reminder of how powerful kindness and empathy can be—especially when someone just needs to be heard.

The film also gently explores the pressure kids face from parents and schools. While the intentions may be good, they can sometimes feel overwhelming. Leo shows how important it is to give children the freedom to grow on their own terms, with support—not control—guiding them.

With its humor, warmth, and powerful messages, Leo turned out to be an unexpected gem. It’s a story that speaks to kids and adults alike, making it perfect for a cozy, meaningful family movie night.

title: The Fascinating World of Cats 🐱
summary: A detailed exploration of the charm, history, types, and care of cats — plus some fun facts and internet links for cat lovers.
content:
The Fascinating World of Cats 🐱

Cats have been companions to humans for thousands of years. With their mysterious charm, graceful movements, and independent spirit, they continue to captivate people across the globe. In this article, we will explore everything that makes cats so fascinating.

History of Cats

Cats were domesticated around 9,000 years ago in the Near East. Ancient Egyptians famously worshipped cats, believing they possessed divine energy. In fact, killing a cat, even accidentally, was punishable by death in ancient Egypt!

Cats were also appreciated for their practical role in controlling rodents in grain stores, which made them valuable in both households and farms.

Types of Cats

There are two broad categories of cats:

1. Domestic Cats (Felis catus)

Domestic cats are the most common type of feline pet. Some popular breeds include:

  • Persian Cats – Known for their long, luxurious fur.
  • Maine Coon – One of the largest domesticated cat breeds.
  • Siamese Cats – Recognizable by their blue almond-shaped eyes and short coat.
  • Bengal Cats – Famous for their leopard-like appearance.

2. Wild Cats

While we love our cuddly domestic cats, their larger cousins roam the wilderness. Some examples are:

  • Lions – The kings of the jungle.
  • Tigers – Solitary and powerful hunters.
  • Leopards – Agile and stealthy predators.

Fun Facts About Cats 😸

  • Cats can rotate their ears 180 degrees.
  • A group of cats is called a clowder.
  • They spend 70% of their lives sleeping — truly masters of relaxation!
  • Cats have an extraordinary ability to land on their feet, thanks to their flexible backbone and vestibular system.

"What greater gift than the love of a cat?"
— Charles Dickens

Caring for Your Cat

Taking care of a cat involves much more than just feeding it. Here are some essential tips:

  • Regular Vet Visits: Ensure your cat is vaccinated and checked for illnesses.
  • Playtime: Cats need mental and physical stimulation.
  • Balanced Diet: Provide nutritious cat food for optimal health.
  • Grooming: Depending on the breed, regular brushing may be necessary.

The Internet’s Love Affair With Cats

Cats rule the internet — from viral videos to Instagram celebrities like Nala Cat. Their quirky behavior, funny reactions, and adorable looks make them perfect for endless entertainment online.

If you want to explore more about cat care, visit this helpful guide on The Humane Society's website.

Conclusion

Cats are more than just pets; they are companions, entertainers, and even healers. Their quiet purrs have been scientifically shown to calm nerves and reduce stress in humans. Whether you are a cat owner or simply an admirer, there’s no denying the special bond that exists between cats and humans.
